name: debt
content:
debt

noun
 
 
/det/
 
/det/
Idioms
jump to other results
  1.  
     [countable] a sum of money that somebody owes
    • to pay/repay a debt
    • I need to pay off all my debts.
    • I've finally cleared all my debts.
    • After settling his debts he was left with just £2000.
    • an outstanding debt of £300
    • He had run up huge credit card debts.
    • They had incurred debts of over $1 million.
    see also carbon debt, national debt, sovereign debt

    • After a series of meetings, the banks were forced to write off the company's debts.

  2.  
     [uncountable] the situation of owing money, especially when you cannot pay
    • in debt He died heavily in debt.
    • The club is £4 million in debt.
    • We were poor but we never got into debt.
    • out of debt It's hard to stay out of debt when you are a student.
    • The country's debt burden is increasing.
    see also bad debt
    Extra Examples
    • a solution to the debt crisis of the developing world
    • We offer financial and debt-management advice.
    • Faced with a mounting burden of debt, he sold off the company.
    • Governments may find it increasingly difficult to manage their debt repayments.
    • She faces a mountain of debt—$60 000 in student loans and $15 000 in credit card balances.

  3. [countable, usually singular] the fact that you should feel grateful to somebody because they have helped you or been kind to you
    • I owe them a debt of gratitude that I can never repay.
    • I would like to acknowledge my debt to my teachers.
    • She was simply repaying a debt, saving his career in return for him saving hers.

    4. Word OriginMiddle English dette: from Old French, based on Latin debitum ‘something owed’, past participle of debere ‘owe’. The spelling change in French and English was by association with the Latin word.
Idioms
be in somebody’s debt
  1. (formal) to feel grateful to somebody for their help, kind behaviour, etc.
    • I am in Ruth's debt for the excellent advice she gave me.

name: carbon debt
content:
carbon debt

noun
 
/ˌkɑːbən ˈdet/
 
/ˌkɑːrbən ˈdet/
jump to other results
  1. the difference between the effects of the carbon footprint of a country, group, person, etc. and anything that has been agreed or done to reduce these effects
    • A massive carbon debt will be created when the forests are harvested.
    • With the continued use of fossil fuels, the country’s carbon debt increases each year.
    Topics The environmentc2

name: national debt
content:
national debt

noun
 
/ˌnæʃnəl ˈdet/
 
/ˌnæʃnəl ˈdet/
 [usually singular]
jump to other results
  1. the total amount of money that the government of a country owes
    • The country has a national debt of 80% of GNP.
    CultureIn Britain, the amount borrowed every year is known as the Public Sector Net Cash Requirement, and is added to the national debt.
    Topics Moneyb2
See national debt in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
